alert.note: Alert for Rutland (Vermont) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Burlington (Northern Vermont and New York)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued July 12 at 1:45AM EDT until July 13 at 2:45AM EDT by NWS Burlington
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Vermont... Otter Creek At Center Rutland affecting Rutland County. For the Otter Creek...including Center Rutland, Middlebury... Moderate flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL JUST AFTER MIDNIGHT TONIGHT... * WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast. This approaches the flood of record. * WHERE...Otter Creek at Center Rutland. * WHEN...Until just after midnight tonight. * IMPACTS...Until the river falls below 9 feet, flooding will continue on low lying roads in Rutland, Clarendon, and Wallingford. Downstream in Proctor and Pittsford, numerous roads will continue to be inundated, and Route 73 west of Brandon will be flood. Route 7 may be threatened by tributaries to Otter Creek in Rutland County. Water will recede when the river level falls below 9 feet, with only low lying areas and field flooding remaining until the level drops below 7 feet. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 12:45 AM EDT Wednesday the stage was 11.7 feet. - Bankfull stage is 8.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 12:45 AM EDT Wednesday was 15.5 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage this evening and continue falling to 6.1 feet Friday evening. - Flood stage is 8.0 feet. - The observed maximum river stage of 16.4 feet is the 2nd highest crest in history. The highest crest in history was observed during Tropical Storm Irene where the stage reached 17.21 feet on 8/29/2011. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued this afternoon at 200 PM EDT.
